title: Ross_Ulbricht
extract: Ross William Ulbricht is an American who created and operated the darknet market website Silk Road from 2011 until his arrest in 2013. He was imprisoned from 2013 until January 2025, when he received a full pardon from U.S. President Donald Trump.
text:
{{Short description|American founder of the Silk Road (born 1984)}} {{Use American English|date=November 2024}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox criminal | name = Ross Ulbricht | image = | alt = | caption = Ulbricht leaving prison after being pardoned in 2025 | birth_name = Ross William Ulbricht | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1984|3|27}} | birth_place = [[Austin, Texas]], U.S. | other_names = Silk Road Admin, SR Admin, Dread Pirate Roberts, DPR, Frosty, Altoid | education = [[University of Texas, Dallas]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]])
[[Pennsylvania State University]] ([[Master of Science|MS]]) | occupation = [[Darknet market]] operator | years_active = February 2011 – October 2013 | agent = | known_for = Creator of [[Silk Road (marketplace)|Silk Road]] | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | height = | weight = | criminal_charge = | motive = | conviction = *[[Continuing Criminal Enterprise Statute|Engaging in a continuing criminal enterprise]] * [[Illegal drug trade in the United States|Distributing narcotics]] * [[Darknet market#Products|Distributing narcotics by means of the Internet]] * [[Conspiracy (criminal)|Conspiring]] to distribute narcotics * Conspiring to commit [[money laundering]] * Conspiring to traffic in [[false identity]] documents * Conspiring to commit [[computer hacking]]{{cite web|title=Ross Ulbricht, A/K/A "Dread Pirate Roberts," Sentenced In Manhattan Federal Court To Life In Prison|date=May 29, 2015|url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/ross-ulbricht-aka-dread-pirate-roberts-sentenced-manhattan-federal-court-life-prison|access-date=March 8, 2022|archive-date=March 8, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220308100227/https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/ross-ulbricht-aka-dread-pirate-roberts-sentenced-manhattan-federal-court-life-prison|url-status=live}} | conviction_penalty = Two consecutive [[Life imprisonment in the United States|life sentences]] without the possibility of [[parole]] plus 40 years and a fine of $183,961,921 | apprehended = October 1, 2013 | website = {{URL|FreeRoss.org}} | criminal_status = [[Pardoned]] by President [[Donald Trump|Trump]] on January 21, 2025 }} '''Ross William Ulbricht''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ʊ|l|b|r|ɪ|k|t}}; born March 27, 1984){{Cite tweet |user=RealRossU |last=Ulbricht |first=Ross |title=I turned 38 yesterday |date=March 28, 2022 |number=1508504339714875392 |access-date=2023-08-28 |language=en}} is an American who created and operated the [[darknet market]] website [[Silk Road (marketplace)|Silk Road]] from 2011 until his arrest in 2013.{{cite news|last1=Raymond|first1=Nate|title=Accused Silk Road operator convicted on U.S. drug charges|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-bitcoin-trial-idUSKBN0L82H920150205|access-date=June 22, 2015|work=Reuters|date=February 4, 2015|archive-date=December 27, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151227110703/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-bitcoin-trial-idUSKBN0L82H920150205|url-status=live}} He was imprisoned from 2013 until January 2025, when he received a full [[pardon]] from [[U.S. President]] [[Donald Trump]]. Silk Road operated as a hidden service on the [[Tor (network)|Tor network]] and was an unrestricted marketplace where buyers could pay in [[bitcoin]]. Some criminals used the website to sell [[narcotic]]s and other illegal products and services. Ulbricht ran the site under the pseudonym "Dread Pirate Roberts", after [[Dread Pirate Roberts|the fictional character]] from ''[[The Princess Bride (novel)|The Princess Bride]].'' In October 2013, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) arrested Ulbricht and took Silk Road offline. In 2015, he was convicted of engaging in a [[Continuing Criminal Enterprise Statute|continuing criminal enterprise]], distributing narcotics by means of the internet, conspiracy to commit [[money laundering]], conspiracy to traffic fraudulent identity documents, and conspiracy to commit [[Hacker (computer security)|computer hacking]].{{cite web|title=Jury Verdict|url=https://www.docketalarm.com/cases/New_York_Southern_District_Court/1--14-cr-00068/USA_v._Ulbricht/183/|publisher=Docket Alarm|access-date=September 27, 2016|archive-date=October 1, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161001184453/https://www.docketalarm.com/cases/New_York_Southern_District_Court/1--14-cr-00068/USA_v._Ulbricht/183/|url-status=live}}{{Cite web |date=2015-05-13 |title=Ross Ulbricht, The Creator And Owner Of The "Silk Road" Website, Found Guilty In Manhattan Federal Court On All Counts |url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/ross-ulbr
trending_reason: The Ross Ulbricht article is likely trending on Wikipedia due to his recent pardon by President Trump on January 21, 2025, marking a significant development in his high-profile criminal case.

title: Silk_Road_(marketplace)
extract: Silk Road was an online black market and the first modern darknet market. It was launched in 2011 by its American founder Ross Ulbricht under the pseudonym "Dread Pirate Roberts." As part of the dark web, Silk Road operated as a hidden service on the Tor network, allowing users to buy and sell products and services between each other anonymously. All transactions were conducted with bitcoin, a cryptocurrency which aided in protecting user identities. The website was known for its illegal drug marketplace, among other illegal and legal product listings. Between February 2011 and July 2013, the site facilitated sales amounting to 9,519,664 Bitcoins.
text:

([[pseudonym]] Dread Pirate Roberts) | launch_date = February 2011 | current_status = Shut down by [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] in October 2013.
Silk Road 2.0 shut down by FBI and [[Europol]] on 6 November 2014.{{Cite web |last=Cook |first=James |date=6 November 2014 |title=FBI Arrests Former SpaceX Employee, Alleging He Ran The 'Deep Web' Drug Marketplace Silk Road 2.0|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/fbi-silk-road-seized-arrests-2014-11 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181225163338/https://www.businessinsider.com/fbi-silk-road-seized-arrests-2014-11 |archive-date=25 December 2018 |access-date=6 November 2014 |website=BusinessInsider.com}}}} '''Silk Road''' was an online [[black market]] and the first modern [[darknet market]].{{Cite web |date=11 February 2018 |title=Case 76: Silk Road (Part 1) - Casefile: True Crime Podcast |work=Casefile: True Crime Podcast |url=http://casefilepodcast.com/case-76-silk-road-part-1/ |url-status=live |access-date=11 June 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612143157/http://casefilepodcast.com/case-76-silk-road-part-1/ |archive-date=12 June 2018}} It was launched in 2011 by its American founder [[Ross Ulbricht]] under the pseudonym "[[Dread Pirate Roberts]]." As part of the [[dark web]],{{Cite web |last=Lee |first=Nicole |date=8 February 2015 |title=Anonymity is dead and other lessons from the Silk Road trial |url=https://www.engadget.com/2015/02/08/silk-road-trial-lessons/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208175515/https://www.engadget.com/2015/02/08/silk-road-trial-lessons/ |archive-date=8 February 2015 |access-date=28 May 2015 |website=engadget.com}} Silk Road operated as a [[.onion|hidden service]] on the [[Tor (network)|Tor network]], allowing users to buy and sell products and services between each other anonymously. All transactions were conducted with [[bitcoin]], a [[cryptocurrency]] which aided in protecting user identities. The website was known for its illegal drug marketplace, among other illegal and legal product listings. Between February 2011 and July 2013, the site facilitated sales amounting to 9,519,664 Bitcoins. In October 2013, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) shut down the Silk Road website and arrested Ulbricht.[[Ars Technica]], [https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/10/how-the-feds-took-down-the-dread-pirate-roberts/ How the feds took down the Dread Pirate Roberts] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210224193315/https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/10/how-the-feds-took-down-the-dread-pirate-roberts/ |date=24 February 2021 }}, 3 October 2013 Silk Road 2.0 came online the next month, run by other administrat

title: List_of_Pixar_films
extract: Pixar Animation Studios is an American CGI film production company based in Emeryville, California, United States. Pixar has produced 28 feature films, which were all released by Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures through the Walt Disney Pictures banner, with its first being Toy Story on November 22, 1995, and its latest being Inside Out 2 on June 14, 2024.
text:
{{Short description|none}} {{pp-protected|small=yes}} {{Use American English|date=December 2022}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2023}} [[File:Pixar logo.svg|right|alt=Pixar logo|310x310px]] [[Pixar|Pixar Animation Studios]] is an American [[computer-generated imagery|CGI]] film production company based in [[Emeryville, California]], United States. Pixar has produced 28 feature films, which were all released by [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures]] through the [[Walt Disney Pictures]] banner, with its first being ''[[Toy Story]]'' (which was also the first CGI-animated feature ever theatrically released) on November 22, 1995, and its latest being ''[[Inside Out 2]]'' on June 14, 2024. Its upcoming slate of films includes ''[[Elio (film)|Elio]]'' in 2025, ''Hoppers'' and ''[[Toy Story 5]]'' in 2026, and ''[[Incredibles 3]]'' at an unspecified date. In addition, an unannounced film is scheduled to be released on June 18, 2027.{{Cite web |last=Vary |first=Adam B. |date=2024-08-02 |title=Marvel Removes 2026 Title, Searchlight's 'A Real Pain' Moves to November in Major Disney Release Date Update |url=https://variety.com/2024/film/news/disney-release-date-update-marvel-a-real-pain-1236094195/ |access-date=2024-08-02 |website=Variety |language=en-US}} {{TOC limit|3}} ==Films== ===Released=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="text-align:center; margin=auto; width:100%;" ! rowspan="2" width="10%" | Film ! rowspan="2" width="10%" | Release date ! rowspan="2" width="10%" | Director(s) ! colspan="2" width="40%" | Writer(s) ! rowspan="2" width="15%" | Producer(s) ! rowspan="2" width="15%" | Composer(s) |- ! width="20%" | Story ! width="20%" | Screenplay |- ! scope="row" style="text-align:center;" | ''[[Toy Story]]'' | {{Date table sorting|November 22, 1995}} | [[John Lasseter]] | [[Pete Docter]], Lasseter, [[Joe Ranft]] & [[Andrew Stanton]] | [[Joel Cohen (writer)|Joel Cohen]], [[Alec Sokolow]], Stanton & [[Joss Whedon]] | [[Bonnie Arnold]] & [[Ralph Guggenheim]] | rowspan="4" | [[Randy Newman]] |- ! scope="row" style="text-align:center;" | ''[[A Bug's Life]]'' | {{Date table sorting|November 25, 1998}} | John Lasseter

title: Diversity,_equity,_and_inclusion
extract: Diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) are organizational frameworks which seek to promote the fair treatment and full participation of all people, particularly groups who have historically been underrepresented or subject to discrimination on the basis of identity or disability. These three notions together represent "three closely linked values" which organizations seek to institutionalize through DEI frameworks. The concepts predate this terminology and other variations sometimes include terms such as belonging, justice, and accessibility. As such, frameworks such as inclusion and diversity (I&D), diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging (DEIB), justice, equity, diversity and inclusion, or diversity, equity, inclusion and accessibility exist.
trending_reason: The Diversity, equity, and inclusion article is likely trending on Wikipedia due to ongoing societal discussions and initiatives surrounding DEI practices, particularly in light of recent legislative developments and corporate commitments to these principles.

  • What is DEI, and why is it dividing America? “The words that the acronym 'DEI' represent sound nice, but it is nothing more than affirmative action and racial preferences by a different name, a system that...

title: Ben_Shelton
extract: Benjamin Todd Shelton is an American professional tennis player. Shelton has a career-high singles ranking of world No. 13 by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP), achieved on August 19, 2024. He has a career-high ATP doubles ranking of No. 68 achieved on May 20, 2024. Shelton has won two singles titles on the ATP Tour, and reached two major semifinals at the 2023 US Open and at the 2025 Australian Open.
text:
{{Short description|American tennis player (born 2002)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2023}} {{Use American English|date=September 2023}} {{for|the former baseball player|Ben Shelton (baseball)}} {{Infobox tennis biography |name = Ben Shelton |image = Shelton MCM23 (27) (52883150181).jpg |caption = Shelton at the [[2023 Monte-Carlo Masters]] |fullname = |country = {{USA}} |residence = [[Gainesville, Florida]], U.S. |birth_date = {{birth date and age|2002|10|9}} |birth_place = [[Atlanta]], Georgia, U.S. |height = {{height|ft=6|in=4}}{{cite web|title=Ben Shelton|url=https://www.atptour.com/en/players/ben-shelton/s0s1/overview|work=[[ATP Tour]]|access-date=15 August 2022|archive-date=February 1, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230201144039/https://www.atptour.com/en/players/ben-shelton/s0s1/overview|url-status=live}} |weight = |turnedpro = 2022 |plays = Left-handed (two-handed backhand) |college = [[University of Florida|Florida]] |coach = [[Bryan Shelton]]
[[Dean Goldfine]] (traveling coach) |careerprizemoney = US $5,497,682 |singlesrecord = {{tennis record|won=76|lost=54}}{{efn|name=record|In [[ATP Tour]] and [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] main draw matches, [[Tennis at the Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]], [[Davis Cup]] and [[Laver Cup]]}} |singlestitles = 2 |highestsinglesranking = No. 13 (August 19, 2024) |currentsinglesranking = No. 20 (January 13, 2025) |AustralianOpenresult = SF ([[2025 Australian Open – Men's singles|2025]]) |FrenchOpenresult = 3R ([[2024 French Open – Men's singles|2024]]) |Wimbledonresult = 4R ([[2024 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|2024]]) |USOpenresult = SF ([[2023 US Open – Men's singles|2023]]) |doublesrecord = {{tennis record|won=27|lost=31}}{{efn|name=record}} |doublestitles = 0 |highestdoublesranking = No. 68 (May 20, 2024) |currentdoublesranking = No. 102 (January 6, 2025) |AustralianOpenDoublesresult = 1R ([[2024 Australian Open – Men's doubles|2024]]) |FrenchOpenDoublesresult = 2R ([[2023 French Open – Men's doubles|2023]]) |WimbledonDoublesresult = 2R ([[2024 Wimbledon Championships – Men's doubles|2024]]) |USOpenDoublesresult = 2R ([[2022 US Open – Men's doubles|2022]]) |USOpenMixedresult = SF ([[2023 US Open – Mixed doubles|2023]]) |updated = January 6, 2025 }} '''Benjamin Todd Shelton'''{{cite web | url=https://m.tennislink.usta.com/rankinghome?Page=PlayerRecord&id=1575929&p=5766&Type=searchresults | title=Find a Ranking or Player Record }} (born October 9, 2002) is an American professional [[tennis]] player. Shelton has a career-high singles ranking of world No. 13 by the [[Association of Tennis Professionals]] (ATP), achieved on August 19, 2024. He has a career-high ATP doubles ranking of No. 68 achieved on May 20, 2024. Shelton has won two singles titles on the [[ATP Tour]], and reached two [[Grand Slam (tennis)#Tournaments|major]] semifinals at the [[2023 US Open – Men's singles|2023 US Open]] and at the [[2025 Australian Open – Men's singles|2025 Australian Open]]. Shelton won the 2016 [[Boys' Junior National Tennis Championship|USTA junior national championship]] in doubles. He played college tennis for the [[Florida Gators men's tennis|Florida Gators]]. As a true freshman in 2021, he clinched the Gators’ first team [[NCAA Men's Tennis Championship|national championship]] with his victory at fifth singles; the following year, he won the men's singles title at the 2022 [[NCAA Division I Tennis Championships]]. That same year, he was named the ITA National Player of the Year.{{Cite web|url=https://www.espn.com/college-sports/story/_/id/34001195/florida-ben-shelton-texas-peyton-stearns-win-ncaa-tennis-singles-titles|title=Florida's Ben Shelton, Texas' Peyton Stearns win NCAA tennis singles titles|work=[[ESPN]]|date=May 28, 2022|access-date=July 16, 2022|archive-date=January 25, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230125101452/https://www.espn.com/college-sports/story/_/id/34001195/florida-ben-shelton-texas-peyton-stearns-win-ncaa-tennis-singles-titles
